turn.3: No it is not a code in the sense that it was coded to do something. People call it a code, but that is not what it is.  We are describing a chemical process after observing it.  These are molecules interacting with each other, not running a predetermined algorithm or something.
turn.4: But it is a predetermined algorithm, isn't it? Isn't it predetermined that an apple seed will grow into an apple tree and not into an orange tree? Is there any chance, no matter how small, that it will grow into an orange tree?
turn.5: No.  The DNA is a combination of chemicals that is different for each species.   This combination makes up the genes.   It wasn't predetermined that this is what would happen.   It evolved that way.  So when the proteins form it does so based on the genes.  This is not the same thing as having it predetermined.  Which is why its not great to call it a code.  A code has an intended purpose.   Additionally the offspring of species don't always copy the DNA correctly from the parents and there is a mutation,  which is how we ultimately get new genes, then new species etc.  In the end it is just chemicals reactions happening.  Physics and the laws of the universe  will just cause this to happen.
